talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources upon notice, on 30 August 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to part (3) of question No. 1665 (Hansard, 28 August 2000, page 17725) concerning vehicle import schemes, (a) has the number of eligible Japanese models decreased from 122 to 20 under the new Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme (SEVS), (b) will the increase in the annual cap for passenger motor vehicles from 25 to 100 to enhance the viability of small operators conflict with the decrease in eligible Japanese models, (c) what is the expected impact of the new registered workshop regime on small business and employment, (d) has he produced a working model which demonstrates the viability of the registered workshop regime and (e) what is the justification for the statement that the Government believes that affected businesses will have ample opportunity to adjust to the new SEVS arrangements.

(2) Further to the answer to part (4) of the question No. 1665, (a) did Low Volume (LV) imports peak at approximately 15,000 vehicles per year in 1999-2000, (b) did Full Volume (FV) imports experience record sales in 1999-2000 and (c) given that LV imports have peaked whilst FV imports continue to rise, do the SEVS regulations place an anti-competitive restriction on LV imports.

(3) Further to the answer to part (6) of the question No. 1665, why have further restrictions been imposed on the LV industry when market forces are controlling the current volumes at approximately 15,000 units per annum.

(4) Further to the answer to part (8) of the question No. 1665, why is a subsidy being provided to the Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme, whilst the Government is effectively closing down the LV industry.
(5) Further to the answer to part (9) of the question No. 1665, which of the Diesel 4WDs are eligible 4WDs.

(6) Further to the answer to part (13) of the question No. 1665, has the Office of Regulation Review given its approval that the Regulatory Impact Statement was conducted in accordance with the prescribed guidelines in demonstrating transparency to all stakeholders.
(7) Further to the answer to part (14) of the question No. 1665, has the level of imports now stabilised at approximately 15,000 units per annum.
(8) Is the LV volume of 14,437 vehicles in 1999 large enough to have an impact on the mainstream motor trade.

(9) What quantity and quality of LV imports would need to be met in order for there to be a demonstrable impact on the Government's and the Motor Vehicle Standards Act's environmental and safety objectives.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) Consistent with our international trade (WTO) obligations, SEVS does not discriminate on the basis of country of origin. The source country of vehicles is not relevant to the treatment under SEVS. As indicated in part (9) to question No. 1665 (Hansard, 28 August 2000, page 17725), some 140 vehicle models from various source countries are expected to be eligible initially under SEVS.

(b) As noted in part (3) of question No. 1665, the increase in the annual cap for PMVs from 25 to 100 vehicles enables importers to apportion fixed costs over higher volumes. The number of vehicle models that will be eligible under SEVS, at any one time, will depend upon model availability and the importing activities of mainstream suppliers.

(c) The Government recognises that there may be additional costs to some small businesses involved in the move to the registered workshop regime under the SEVS. Stakeholder representatives have been involved in consultations with officials on ways to minimise these costs while maintaining the integrity of the workshop regime.

(d) The registered workshop regime announced by the Government is consistent with the review of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 (MVSA). All major stakeholder groups supported this approach. To facilitate the operation of the registered workshop regime, the Government has asked the SEVS administrator (the Department of Transport and Regional Services) to make allowance for the carryover of genuine vehicle test evidence to the new scheme, backed by anti-fraud measures, to ensure that the used vehicle trade is not subject to unnecessary and avoidable red tape. The administrator will also be required, as part of his consultation with key stakeholders on the SEVS implementation, to examine means to minimise the cost of participation in the registered workshop regime while maintaining the requirement for cost recovery. The MVSA review recommended a reasonable transition to the new arrangements.
(e) See response to (d)

(2) (a) Entries under the LVS reached record levels in 1999-2000 with approximately 16,000 entries approved. Between 1993 and 1999, entries under the LVS have risen at an annual average rate of 55 per cent.
(b) New vehicle imports entered under normal arrangements declined by 2.3 per cent to 503,000 in 1999-2000.

(c) Low volume vehicles enter Australia under concessional arrangements compared with vehicles marketed under normal arrangements. Although the Government has modified the conditions attached to those concessional arrangements a system of low volume entry remains in place.

(3) The interaction of supply and demand will ultimately determine the level of activity in any market. The rationale for the introduction of SEVS is to provide a regulatory structure capable of better achieving the safety and environmental objectives of the MVSA and equity between operators in different segments of the vehicle market.

(4) The Government is not prohibiting the importation of used vehicles under concessional arrangements. The LVS is being replaced with the SEVS. The objectives behind the introduction of the Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme are contained in part (8) of question No. 1665.

(5) The Government is currently aware of 10 four wheel drive models that are expected to meet SEVS eligibility requirements on merits other than engine type. They are the: Dodge Durango; Ibex 240,250, 280; Isuzu Mu (Ute); Isuzu Vehicross; Jeep Commanche (Ute); Lexus RX 300; Mitsubishi RVR; Nissan Atlas Condor (Ute); SVM 3000 4x4; and Toyota Harrier. Petrol and diesel engine variants (if produced) of these models will be eligible for entry under SEVS.
(6) As noted in part (13) of question No. 1665, the response remains the same.
(7) In 1999, used vehicles imported under LVS grew by 86.4 per cent to 14,437. See part (2) (a).
(8) Yes, it is for example the number of vehicles entered under the LVS in 1999 is equivalent to the whole of the new motor vehicle market in Tasmania.

(9) The integrity of national safety and emission standards under the MVSA will be maintained, providing vehicles introduced to the Australian market under concessional arrangements remain low. SEVS will ensure that the Government's environmental and safety objectives set out under the MVSA are adhered to.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 6 September 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to his decision to award a proportion of permanent visa positions to the temporary-entry visa scheme in the year 1999-2000, how many of the 10 000 permanent visa positions were awarded to the temporary entry protection visa scheme.
(2) Were the remaining permanent visa positions filled in the 1999-2000; if not, what happened to those positions.

(3) If temporary protection visa recipients are awarded permanent residency in three years time, will he guarantee that they will not be taken from that year's refugee program, but will be counted as part of the 1999-2000 program.

(4) If he can give this guarantee in relation to the 1999-2000 program, can he also give a guarantee that such a practice will be carried out in relation to the refugee programs for 2000-2001, 2001-2002 and 2002-2003.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) At the beginning of the 1999-2000 program year there were 12,841 places available under the Humanitarian Program. This consisted of:
- the allocation of 12,000 places decided by the Government;
- 841 unused placed carried over from the previous year and places of people who had been granted a visa but who did not use the visa to travel to Australia.
There were 2,458 protection visas granted in 1999-2000 of which 873 were temporary protection visas (TPVs).
(2) In 1999-2000 there were 7,502 offshore grants and 2,458 onshore grants. The remaining 2,881 unfilled places were brought forward into 2000-01.

(3) Recipients of temporary protection visas are counted against the Humanitarian Program in the year of grant of the TPV. Should a TPV holder apply for a permanent protection visa (PPV) and be found after 30 months to still require protection and is granted a PPV, the PPV holder will not be counted again in the Humanitarian Program.
(4) Please see answer to Question (3).

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney Airports Corporation Ltd: Pricing Proposal
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1948)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 7 September 2000:

quote.para: (1) With respect to the Sydney Airport pricing proposal, why was the industry consultative meeting scheduled for 10 August 2000 cancelled at the request of Sydney Airports Corporation Ltd (SACL).
(2) When will the Revised Draft Proposal be available for review by the airlines.

(3) Will the airlines be guaranteed an opportunity to review and comment on the SACL revised Draft Proposal before it is submitted to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission for determination.
(4) To what extent is the Minister's office and the Minister's Department consulted in finalising the SACL pricing proposals.

(5) Should the SACL include as part of its pricing proposal a Service Level Agreement with airport users, including compensation to airlines for any failure by SACL to deliver services to the specified standard.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Revised Draft Proposal was not available prior to 10 August, and in line with the agreed process, SACL advised airlines that the meeting would not proceed. SACL have undertaken to reschedule the meeting once a firm release date for the Draft Proposal is known.
(2) SACL will provide the airlines with a Revised Draft Proposal as soon as practicable.

(3) SACL have been consulting with airlines regarding its draft aeronautical pricing proposal since December 1999. SACL has committed to the airlines that it will continue consulting with them while the ACCC commences its formal consideration of the proposal.

(4) The Minister's Office and the Minister's Department have been consulted in finalising the SACL pricing proposals to the extent required by Part 1.3.G of the Governance Arrangements for Commonwealth Government Business Enterprises (GBEs), which provides that all GBEs must consult with Shareholder Ministers on matters of significance.

(5) SACL is committed to developing Service Level Agreements (SLAs) with its customers, and has initiated discussions on developing them with airlines. It is appropriate for SACL to seek a determination on the level for aeronautical charges before reaching Service Level Agreements with its customers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 7 September 2000:

quote.para: (1) What is the current status of Australia's trade relations with (a) Romania, (b) Croatia and (c) Hungary.
(2) What are the current levels of imports and exports to or from those countries.
(3) How do the levels compare, on a year-by-year basis, since 1995.
(4) Is he satisfied with the current situation of trade relations with these nations.
(5) What initiatives have been implemented by him to improve these trade relations.
(6) Are there any identifiable problems in trade with nations of Eastern Europe.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Australia's level of trade with Romania, Croatia and Hungary is modest. In 1999, total two-way merchandise trade with these three countries was valued at:
(a) Romania - $82m, Australia's 67th most important partner for merchandise trade;
(b) Croatia - $11m, Australia's 118th most important partner for merchandise trade and
(c) Hungary - $71m, Australia's 68th most important partner for merchandise trade.
(2) In 1999, imports from, and exports to, these countries were valued at:
(a) Romania - $8m (mainly clothing, footwear, electrical machinery, tractors) and $74m (mainly coal, other ores, iron ore, wool,) respectively;
(b) Croatia - $9m (mainly food products) and $2 m (mainly bovine meat) respectively;

(c) Hungary - $66m (mainly computers, motor vehicle parts, electrical machinery, rubber tyres, radio broadcast receivers) and $5m (mainly telecommunications equipment, wool, computer parts) respectively.
(3) The levels of imports from, and exports to, Romania, Croatia and Hungary, have fluctuated on a yearly basis since 1995:
(a) Romania
Imports: 1995 - $12.3m; 1996 - $10.4m; 1997 - $8.1m; 1998 - $7m; 1999 - $8m. Imports over the period between 1994 and 1999 have declined by a trend rate of 9.9%.
Exports: 1995 - $86.2m; 1996 - $104.8m; 1997 - $105.3m; 1998 - $82.3m; 1999 - $74m. Exports over the period between 1994 and 1999 have increased by a trend rate of 6.4%.
(b) Croatia
Imports: 1995 - $8.5m; 1996 - $7.0m; 1997 - $7.4m; 1998 - $8.8m; 1999 - $9m. Imports over the period between 1994 and 1999 have increased by a trend rate of 0.6%.
Exports: 1995 - $12.6m; 1996 - $3.1m; 1997 - $12.3m; 1998 - $7.1m; 1999 - $2m. Exports over the period between 1994 and 1999 have declined by a trend rate of 9.5%.
(c) Hungary
Imports: 1995 - $38.9m; 1996 - $30.1m; 1997 - $45m; 1998 - $67.2m; 1999 - $66m. Imports over the period between 1994 and 1999 have increased by a trend rate of 16.0%.
Exports: 1995 - $4.3m; 1996 - $5.8m; 1997 - $8.5m; 1998 - $12.8m; 1999 - $5m. Exports over the period between 1994 and 1999 have increased by a trend rate of 12.3%.

(4) Australia's current trade flows with Romania, Croatia and Hungary should be seen in the context of these countries' gradual transition from centralised command economies to market-based economies. The Australian Government would, of course, like to see the levels of trade expand. There are prospects this may occur, as the Governments of these countries continue to implement structural reforms and integrate their economies fully with the global economic system, including their prospective accession, in due course, to the European Union.

(5) The Australian Government has taken several initiatives in recent years to enhance trade with Romania, Croatia and Hungary. In October 1999, I led an Australian business delegation to Romania and chaired the Australia-Romania Mixed Commission. This mission served to identify several new trade opportunities. I also officially opened the Consulate-General in Bucharest, the main role of which is to identify trade opportunities for Australian exporters. One of the main objectives behind the Government's decision to upgrade its Consulate in Zagreb to an Embassy in 1999 was to facilitate and promote Australia's commercial links with Croatia. An Austrade marketing officer has recently been appointed to the Embassy in Zagreb, with the specific task of improving trade and investment relations with Croatia. The Government's Market Development Task Force has this year identified Hungary as a priority market for increased coal exports. The Government also takes every opportunity to lobby for the removal of both tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade with these countries, in many cases a legacy of the communist era.

(6) The significant economic restructuring in the countries of Central and East Europe is leading to changes in these countries' trading patterns. A major challenge will lie in positioning more Australian companies to seize emerging market opportunities. In addition, the efforts of these countries to align their economies more closely with that of the EU, with a view to eventual EU accession, could reduce their focus on trade opportunities outside Europe. The Australian Government will continue to encourage these countries to ensure that their close integration into European economic structures results in creation of, rather than diversion of, trade opportunities, including with Australia.
